title: Quiz 3: NCK Paper One - July 2014
description: Examination for Admission to the Register of Community Health Nurses (Basic) - July 2014. Covers Medical-Surgical, Pharmacology, and Nursing Fundamentals.

questions.question: A patient with increased intracranial pressure will present with:
questions.explanation: Projectile Vomiting (often without nausea) is a hallmark sign of increased ICP. While Cushing's Triad involves Bradycardia (not Tachycardia) and Hypertension, projectile vomiting is the most distinct neurological sign listed in the correct option context.
questions.hint: Look for a specific type of vomiting associated with neurological pressure.

questions.question: The microbes associated with food poisoning include:

options.text: Staphylococcus aureus, campylobacter jejuni, vibrio cholerae.
Streptococcus pyogenes, Klebsiella pneumoniae, staphylococcus epidermidis.
Staphylococcus aureus, salmonella Typhimurium, campylobacter jejuni.

questions.explanation: Staph aureus (toxins), Salmonella, and Campylobacter are classic enteric pathogens associated with food poisoning from contaminated food sources.
questions.hint: Common causes include poultry, eggs, and dairy contamination.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements regarding anatomy: 
1. The left kidney is slightly lower than the right kidney. 
2. The nasal part of the pharynx has stratified squamous epithelium.

options.text: Statement 1 is True, Statement 2 is False.
Statement 1 is False, Statement 2 is True.

questions.explanation: 1. False: The RIGHT kidney is lower due to the liver. 2. False: The nasopharynx has respiratory epithelium (pseudostratified ciliated columnar); the oropharynx has squamous epithelium.
questions.hint: Think about the liver's position and the function of the nose (filtering).

questions.question: Cushing's syndrome commonly presents with:

options.text: Facial hair, acne, enlargement of the clitoris.

questions.explanation: Cushing's syndrome involves excess cortisol and androgens. Clinical signs of virilization in women include hirsutism (facial hair), acne, and clitoral enlargement.
questions.hint: Signs of excess androgens.

questions.question: Seborrheic dermatoses commonly affects the following parts of the body:

options.text: Lower limbs, the back and axillae.
The neck, groins and calf region.
Gluteal crease, the back and abdomen.

questions.explanation: Seborrheic dermatitis affects areas rich in sebaceous glands and skin folds, such as behind ears, eyelids, and under breasts.
questions.hint: Think about oily areas and skin folds.

questions.question: A correct nursing diagnosis for a patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is:

options.text: "Pulmonary potential for respiratory failure related to lungs degeneration".
"Ineffective individual coping related to lower activity level".
"Delayed recovery due to poor tolerance of activity and medication".

questions.explanation: Option C follows the proper NANDA format and reflects the psychosocial impact of the disease. Other options are malformed or have incorrect etiologies.
questions.hint: Look for the correctly structured NANDA diagnosis statement.

questions.question: The common features associated with pathophysiology of asthma include:

options.text: Alveoli hyperinflation, mediastinal shift and swelling of membranes.
Bronchial muscle enlargement, filling of bronchi with thick mucus.
Contraction of bronchial muscles, atrophy of mucus membranes.
Air trapping in the alveoli, contraction of bronchial muscles, production of tenacious sputum.

questions.explanation: The Asthma Triad: Bronchospasm (muscle contraction), Inflammation/Edema, and Mucus production leading to Air Trapping.
questions.hint: Bronchospasm + Mucus + Air Trapping.

questions.question: Following hemorrhoidectomy the nurse should:

options.text: Ensure the patient sits on a soft cushion for the first three days.
Advise the patient to only request for a bland diet.
Ensure the patient has a sitz bath after every bowel action.
Remove the anal pack 8 hours after the surgery.

questions.explanation: Sitz baths promote cleanliness, reduce pain, and increase blood flow to aid healing, especially after bowel movements.
questions.hint: A warm water bath for the perineal area.

questions.question: Pernicious anaemia is associated with:

options.text: Gastrectomy, autoimmune destruction of gastric parietal cells.
Vit B6 deficiency excess folic acid.
Deficiency of folic acid, excess intake of niacin.
Partial gastrectomy, vitamin B2 and B6 deficiency.

questions.explanation: Pernicious anemia is caused by lack of Intrinsic Factor (produced by gastric parietal cells) needed to absorb Vitamin B12. Gastrectomy removes these cells.
questions.hint: Lack of Intrinsic Factor.

questions.question: A late manifestation of compartment syndrome is:
questions.explanation: Pulselessness is a very late and ominous sign indicating pressure has exceeded arterial pressure. Pain is the earliest sign.
questions.hint: The 5th P, indicating arterial flow has stopped.

questions.question: Indicators for inhalational burns are:

options.text: History of the burn occurring in an enclosed area, singed nasal hair, anaemia.
Singed nasal hair, the burn occurring in an enclosed area, sooty sputum.

questions.explanation: Triad: Enclosed space history, facial signs (singed hair), and carbonaceous (sooty) sputum.
questions.hint: Look for signs of smoke exposure in the face and airway.

questions.question: Which statement by a patient post total mastectomy (left side) indicates effective teaching?

options.text: "I will ensure my left arm is always at rest."
"On discharge from hospital, I shall buy heavy duty gloves to wear when gardening."
"I should have a prosthesis implant strictly after 1 year."
"There is no harm carrying my handbags on either shoulder."

questions.explanation: Patients must protect the affected arm from injury (cuts, scratches) to prevent infection/lymphedema. Gardening gloves are a protective measure.
questions.hint: Prevention of injury to the affected limb.

questions.question: The ratio of replacing crystalloids blood loss in haemorrhagic shock management is:
questions.explanation: Standard resuscitation guideline: Replace 1 mL blood loss with 3 mL crystalloid to account for fluid shift to interstitial space.
questions.hint: You need three times the volume of saline.

questions.question: Following functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS), the nurse should:

options.text: Assist the patient to brush teeth 8 hours after surgery.
Nurse the patient in Trendelenburg position.
Remove the nasal pack 12 hours post surgery.
Encourage the patient to breath through the mouth.

questions.explanation: Nasal packing prevents nasal breathing. Mouth breathing is necessary. Trendelenburg increases bleeding risk.
questions.hint: The nose is packed, so the airway must be...

questions.question: Predisposing factors to retinal detachment include:
questions.explanation: Myopia (elongated eye thins retina), Trauma, and Cataract surgery are major risk factors.
questions.hint: Nearsightedness is a risk factor.

questions.question: Cancer that gets cured through chemotherapy is:
questions.explanation: Burkitt's lymphoma is highly chemosensitive and often curable with chemotherapy alone.
questions.hint: A type of Lymphoma.

questions.question: Causes of functional intestinal obstruction include:
questions.explanation: Functional obstruction (Paralytic Ileus) is caused by Peritonitis or Electrolyte imbalances (usually Hypokalemia, though this option pairs peritonitis with an electrolyte issue).
questions.hint: Think paralytic ileus, not mechanical blockage.

questions.question: The clinical features for kidney rejection post transplantation include:

options.text: Tenderness on the area, weight gain, Hypokalemia.

questions.explanation: Rejection mimics renal failure: Oliguria (low urine), Weight gain (fluid retention), and Hypertension.
questions.hint: Signs that the kidney is failing to filter fluid.

questions.question: Warning signs for a patient with a fracture on the base of the skull are:
questions.explanation: Basilar skull fracture signs: Raccoon eyes (periorbital bruising), Battle's sign (mastoid bruising), and Otorrhea (CSF from ear).
questions.hint: Bruising around eyes and behind ears.

questions.question: The properties of general anesthesia are:

options.text: Loss of consciousness, amnesia and analgesia.
Partial loss of consciousness, muscle relaxation and amnesia.

questions.explanation: The Triad of General Anesthesia: Hypnosis (Unconsciousness), Analgesia (Pain relief), and Muscle Relaxation.
questions.hint: Sleep, Pain relief, Relaxation.

questions.question: Identify common errors in formulation of a nursing diagnosis: (Select 4)

options.text: Stating the problem as an intervention.

questions.explanation: Errors include using medical terms (Pneumonia vs Airway Clearance), stating interventions (Catheterize vs Retention), or judgmental terms (Uncooperative).
questions.hint: Focus on what you should NOT do.

questions.question: Match the characteristic of Humulin Insulin to its correct value:
questions.explanation: Humulin R is a short-acting insulin taken before meals.
questions.hint: Regular insulin kinetics.

questions.question: Which of the following are functions of Thyroid Hormones?
questions.explanation: T3/T4 regulate metabolism, growth, and heart function. Calcitonin (also from Thyroid) regulates calcium, but 'Thyroid Hormones' usually refers to T3/T4.
questions.hint: Think about energy and growth.

questions.question: Select the indications for Parenteral Feeding:

options.text: Functional GI tract with difficulty swallowing.

questions.explanation: Parenteral feeding (TPN) is used when the GI tract cannot be used. If the gut works, enteral feeding is preferred.
questions.hint: When the gut cannot work or needs total rest.

questions.question: Arrange the management steps for an adult with foreign body airway obstruction (FBAU) who has a weak cough:
questions.explanation: Assess -> Help -> Back Blows -> Abdominal Thrusts -> Repeat.
questions.hint: Back first, then abdomen.

questions.question: What health messages should be shared with a patient post-Myocardial Infarction?
questions.explanation: Lifestyle changes (Diet, Smoking) and Medication adherence are critical to prevent recurrence.
questions.hint: Heart healthy lifestyle.

questions.question: Which of the following are late manifestations of Cervical Cancer?
questions.explanation: Early cancer is often asymptomatic. Late signs involve spread to nerves (pain), bladder/rectum (bleeding), and necrosis (discharge).
questions.hint: Signs of advanced spread.

questions.question: Case Study: Mr. T has Acute Pancreatitis. Select the correct Pathophysiology and Management:

richContent.content:
Case: Acute Pancreatitis

Mr. T, 40, presents with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back.

options.text: Pathophysiology: Autodigestion of pancreas by activated enzymes.
Management: Strict NPO (Nil Per Os) status.
Management: Force feed high fat diet.

questions.explanation: Autodigestion causes inflammation. Management focuses on Resting the Pancreas (NPO), Pain control, and Fluids to prevent shock.
questions.hint: Rest the gut and hydrate.

questions.question: Case Study: Mr. S needs a Total Hip Replacement (THR). What are the key care points?

richContent.content:
Case: Total Hip Replacement

Mr. S has chronic osteoarthritis and is scheduled for surgery.

options.text: Post-op: Maintain abduction of legs (Abduction pillow).
Post-op: Flex hip >90 degrees to stretch muscles.

questions.explanation: Infections must be cleared pre-op. Post-op priority is preventing dislocation (Abduction, No flexion >90) and complications (DVT).
questions.hint: Prevent dislocation and infection.

questions.question: Match the columns regarding Post-Operative Care:
questions.explanation: Standard post-op care matches specific risks with interventions.
questions.hint: Match the complication to the prevention method.
